articles.title: Fatty liver breakthrough: A safe, cheap vitamin shows promise
articles.summary: Researchers identified microRNA-93 as a genetic driver of fatty liver disease and showed that vitamin B3 can effectively suppress it. This breakthrough suggests niacin could be repurposed as a powerful new treatment for millions worldwide.
articles.content:
Approximately 30% of the global population is affected by metabolic-associated fatty liver disease (MASLD), a condition that previously lacked targeted treatments. In a groundbreaking discovery, researchers have identified a genetic factor that exacerbates the disease, and remarkably, the FDA-approved drug that most effectively targets this factor is vitamin B3.

A collaborative research team led by Professor Jang Hyun Choi from the Department of Life Sciences at UNIST, in partnership with Professor Hwayoung Yun from the College of Pharmacy and Research Institute for Drug Development at Pusan National University (PNU), and Professor Neung Hwa Park from Ulsan University Hospital (UUH), has, for the first time globally, elucidated the role of microRNA-93 (miR-93), which is expressed in the liver, as a key genetic regulator in the development and progression of MASLD.

MiR-93 is a specialized RNA molecule expressed in hepatocytes that functions to suppress the expression of specific target genes. The team observed abnormally elevated levels of miR-93 in both patients with fatty liver disease and animal models. Through molecular analysis, they demonstrated that miR-93 promotes lipid accumulation, inflammation, and fibrosis by inhibiting the expression of SIRT1, a gene involved in lipid metabolism within liver cells.

In experiments utilizing gene editing techniques to eliminate miR-93 production in mice, researchers observed a marked reduction in hepatic fat accumulation, along with significant improvements in insulin sensitivity and liver function indicators. Conversely, mice with overexpressed miR-93 exhibited worsened hepatic metabolic function.

Furthermore, screening 150 FDA-approved drugs revealed that niacin (vitamin B3) most effectively suppresses miR-93. Mice treated with niacin showed a significant decrease in hepatic miR-93 levels and a notable increase in SIRT1 activity. The activated SIRT1 restored disrupted lipid metabolism pathways, thereby normalizing liver lipid homeostasis.

The research team explained, "This study precisely elucidates the molecular origin of MASLD and demonstrates the potential for repurposing an already approved vitamin compound to modulate this pathway, which has high translational clinical relevance."

They added, "Given that niacin is a well-established and safe medication used to treat hyperlipidemia, it holds promise as a candidate for combination therapies targeting miRNA pathways in MASLD."

This research was supported by various including the National Research Foundation of Korea (NRF) and the Korea Research Institute of Bioscience and Biotechnology (KRIBB). The findings were published online in the prestigious biomedical journal, Metabolism: Clinical and Experimental. Participants include Dr. Yo Han Lee and Kieun Park from UNIST, along with Professor Joonho Jeong from Ulsan University Hospital and Jinyoung Lee from Pusan National University, as co-first authors.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant medical breakthrough identifying a genetic driver of fatty liver disease and demonstrating that vitamin B3 (niacin), an already approved and safe drug, can effectively suppress this driver. This discovery has broad implications for treating a condition affecting about 30% of the global population, offering a potentially accessible and affordable therapy with substantial positive health impact worldwide.
articles.personality_title: Vitamin B3 shows promise in treating fatty liver disease by targeting key gene
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – About 30% of people worldwide have metabolic-associated fatty liver disease (MASLD), a condition where fat builds up in the liver and causes health problems. Until now, there were no specific treatments that directly target the causes of this disease.

**What happened** – Researchers from South Korea discovered that a molecule called microRNA-93 (miR-93) plays a major role in worsening MASLD. This molecule is found in liver cells and causes fat to build up, leading to inflammation and scarring. By studying mice, scientists found that removing miR-93 improved liver health. They also tested 150 approved drugs and found that vitamin B3, also known as niacin, could lower miR-93 levels and help restore normal liver function.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because niacin is already a safe and affordable vitamin used for other health issues like high cholesterol. Finding that it can also reduce miR-93 means it might be repurposed as a new treatment for MASLD. This could help millions of people worldwide with a simple and accessible option.

**What's next step** – The research team will likely move toward clinical trials to test niacin’s effectiveness in humans with fatty liver disease. They also plan to explore combining niacin with other treatments to improve results.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists found that vitamin B3 can target a key genetic factor in fatty liver disease, offering a promising, affordable treatment option for millions.
articles.personality_title_fr: La vitamine B3 promet un traitement contre la maladie du foie gras en ciblant un gène clé
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Environ 30 % de la population mondiale souffre de la maladie du foie gras métabolique (MASLD), une maladie où la graisse s'accumule dans le foie, causant des problèmes de santé. Jusqu'à présent, il n'existait pas de traitements ciblant directement les causes de cette maladie.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs sud-coréens ont découvert qu'une molécule appelée microARN-93 (miR-93) joue un rôle majeur dans l'aggravation de la MASLD. Cette molécule, présente dans les cellules du foie, provoque l'accumulation de graisse, entraînant inflammation et cicatrisation. En étudiant des souris, les scientifiques ont constaté que supprimer le miR-93 améliorait la santé du foie. Ils ont également testé 150 médicaments approuvés et trouvé que la vitamine B3, aussi appelée niacine, pouvait réduire les niveaux de miR-93 et aider à restaurer la fonction normale du foie.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car la niacine est déjà une vitamine sûre et abordable utilisée pour d'autres problèmes de santé comme le cholestérol élevé. Trouver qu'elle peut aussi réduire le miR-93 signifie qu'elle pourrait être réutilisée comme nouveau traitement contre la MASLD. Cela pourrait aider des millions de personnes dans le monde avec une option simple et accessible.

**Prochaine étape** – L'équipe de recherche devrait passer à des essais cliniques pour tester l'efficacité de la niacine chez les personnes atteintes de la maladie du foie gras. Ils prévoient aussi d'explorer la combinaison de la niacine avec d'autres traitements pour améliorer les résultats.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont découvert que la vitamine B3 peut cibler un facteur génétique clé de la maladie du foie gras, offrant une option de traitement prometteuse et abordable pour des millions de personnes.
articles.personality_title_es: La vitamina B3 muestra potencial para tratar la enfermedad del hígado graso al atacar un gen clave
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Aproximadamente el 30 % de la población mundial tiene enfermedad del hígado graso metabólico (MASLD), una condición donde se acumula grasa en el hígado causando problemas de salud. Hasta ahora, no había tratamientos que atacaran directamente las causas de esta enfermedad.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de Corea del Sur descubrieron que una molécula llamada microARN-93 (miR-93) desempeña un papel importante en el empeoramiento de la MASLD. Esta molécula, presente en las células del hígado, provoca acumulación de grasa, inflamación y cicatrices. Al estudiar ratones, encontraron que eliminar el miR-93 mejoraba la salud del hígado. También probaron 150 medicamentos aprobados y encontraron que la vitamina B3, conocida como niacina, podía reducir los niveles de miR-93 y ayudar a restaurar la función normal del hígado.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo es importante porque la niacina ya es una vitamina segura y económica que se usa para otros problemas de salud como el colesterol alto. Descubrir que también puede reducir el miR-93 significa que podría usarse como un nuevo tratamiento para la MASLD. Esto podría ayudar a millones de personas con una opción simple y accesible.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo de investigación probablemente avanzará hacia ensayos clínicos para probar la efectividad de la niacina en personas con enfermedad del hígado graso. También planean explorar combinaciones de niacina con otros tratamientos para mejorar los resultados.

**Frase clave** – Los científicos encontraron que la vitamina B3 puede atacar un factor genético clave en la enfermedad del hígado graso, ofreciendo una opción de tratamiento prometedora y económica para millones.

articles.title: One daily habit could save you from chronic back pain
articles.summary: Walking every day could be the simplest and most effective way to prevent chronic lower back pain. A large study involving over 11,000 people found that walking more — not faster — reduces the risk of developing long-term back issues. The findings show that even low-intensity walking provides protection, with participants walking over 100 minutes daily experiencing significantly lower risks than those walking less.
articles.content:
A major study has investigated the relationship between walking and the risk of developing chronic lower back problems. The findings could save the healthcare system significant amounts of money while also alleviating many people's back pain - if we just follow the simple advice provided.

The results are clear: People who walk a lot have less back pain than people who do not walk much - and the volume is what matters most, not the intensity.. It is better to walk a lot than to walk fast.

"People who walk more than 100 minutes every day have a 23 per cent lower risk of lower back problems than those who walk 78 minutes or less," said Rayane Haddadj.

He is a PhD candidate at the Department of Public Health and Nursing at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology (NTNU), and is part of a research group that specifically studies musculoskeletal disorders.

The results of the new study were published in the JAMA Network Open journal. The article has already received a lot of attention.

Even leisurely strolls are beneficial

It probably comes as no surprise that physical activity is good for your back, but until now we have not actually known whether the amount of low-intensity walking we do also helps.

"Intensity also plays a role in the risk of long-term back problems, but not as much as the daily amount of walking," emphasized Haddadj.

A total of 11,194 people participated in the study, which is part of the Trøndelag Health Study (The HUNT Study). What makes this study unique is that the volume and intensity of daily walking were measured using two sensors that participants wore on their thigh and back for up to a week.

The results may be important in relation to preventing chronic back problems. Until now, there has been little research on the prevention of these types of musculoskeletal problems. It is well known that physical activity can prevent a wide range of illnesses and ailments. This study is important because it confirms that physical activity, and especially daily walking, can help prevent long-term lower back problems.

Back pain is a very common ailment

"The findings highlight the importance of finding time to be physically active - to prevent both chronic back problems and a number of other diseases. Over time, this could lead to major savings for society," said Paul Jarle Mork, a professor at NTNU's Department of Public Health and Nursing.

Back and neck problems cost society several billion kroner every year. Musculoskeletal disorders are likely the largest expense within the Norwegian healthcare system.

Back pain is one of the most common health problems in Norway. Depending on what you include, between 60 and 80 per cent of us will experience back problems at some point in our lives. At any given time, around one in five Norwegians has back trouble.

The causes are many and complex, but the solution might be as simple as putting on your shoes and going for a walk - each and every day.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant, large-scale study demonstrating that daily walking substantially reduces the risk of chronic lower back pain, a common and costly health issue. The findings provide clear, actionable advice with broad public health implications, potentially improving quality of life and reducing healthcare costs.
articles.personality_title: Daily walking reduces risk of chronic lower back pain, study finds
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Back pain is one of the most common health problems worldwide. Many people suffer from long-term lower back pain, which can be costly for healthcare systems and affect daily life.

**What happened** – A large study in Norway involving over 11,000 people measured how much and how intensely they walked each day. Researchers found that those who walked more than 100 minutes daily had a 23% lower risk of developing chronic lower back pain compared to those who walked less than 78 minutes. The study showed that the total amount of walking matters more than how fast people walk.

**Impact** – This is important because it provides clear evidence that even gentle, low-intensity walking can help prevent long-term back problems. Since back pain affects many people and costs healthcare systems billions, encouraging daily walking could improve many lives and save money.

**What’s next step** – Health experts may use this information to promote walking as a simple way to prevent back pain. Future research could explore how to motivate people to walk more every day and study if similar benefits occur in other countries.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Walking for more than 100 minutes daily can significantly lower the risk of chronic lower back pain, making it a simple and effective way to protect your back.
articles.personality_title_fr: Une promenade quotidienne réduit le risque de douleurs lombaires chroniques, selon une étude
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les douleurs dorsales sont l’un des problèmes de santé les plus fréquents dans le monde. Beaucoup de personnes souffrent de douleurs lombaires à long terme, ce qui coûte cher aux systèmes de santé et affecte la vie quotidienne.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une grande étude en Norvège, avec plus de 11 000 participants, a mesuré la durée et l’intensité de la marche quotidienne. Les chercheurs ont découvert que ceux qui marchaient plus de 100 minutes par jour avaient un risque réduit de 23 % de développer des douleurs lombaires chroniques, comparé à ceux qui marchaient moins de 78 minutes. L’étude montre que la quantité totale de marche compte plus que la vitesse.

**Impact** – C’est important car cela prouve que même une marche douce et peu intense peut aider à prévenir les problèmes de dos à long terme. Comme les douleurs dorsales touchent beaucoup de personnes et coûtent des milliards, encourager la marche quotidienne pourrait améliorer la vie de beaucoup et économiser de l’argent.

**Prochaine étape** – Les experts en santé pourraient utiliser ces informations pour promouvoir la marche comme moyen simple de prévenir les douleurs dorsales. Des recherches futures pourraient étudier comment motiver les gens à marcher davantage chaque jour et voir si ces bénéfices s’appliquent aussi dans d’autres pays.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Marcher plus de 100 minutes par jour peut réduire significativement le risque de douleurs lombaires chroniques, en faisant une méthode simple et efficace pour protéger son dos.
articles.personality_title_es: Caminar diariamente reduce el riesgo de dolor lumbar crónico, según estudio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El dolor de espalda es uno de los problemas de salud más comunes en el mundo. Muchas personas sufren dolor lumbar a largo plazo, lo que genera altos costos para los sistemas de salud y afecta la vida diaria.

**Qué pasó** – Un gran estudio en Noruega con más de 11,000 personas midió cuánto y con qué intensidad caminaban cada día. Los investigadores encontraron que quienes caminaban más de 100 minutos diarios tenían un 23 % menos de riesgo de desarrollar dolor lumbar crónico en comparación con quienes caminaban menos de 78 minutos. El estudio mostró que la cantidad total de caminata es más importante que la velocidad.

**Impacto** – Esto es importante porque demuestra que incluso caminar suavemente y con baja intensidad puede ayudar a prevenir problemas de espalda a largo plazo. Dado que el dolor de espalda afecta a muchas personas y cuesta miles de millones, fomentar la caminata diaria podría mejorar muchas vidas y ahorrar dinero.

**Próximo paso** – Los expertos en salud podrían usar esta información para promover la caminata como una forma sencilla de prevenir el dolor de espalda. Investigaciones futuras podrían explorar cómo motivar a las personas a caminar más cada día y estudiar si estos beneficios ocurren en otros países.

**Resumen en una frase** – Caminar más de 100 minutos al día puede reducir significativamente el riesgo de dolor lumbar crónico, siendo una forma simple y efectiva de cuidar la espalda.
